Tiberio Caesare tertium Germanico Caesare iterum consulibus
Cnaeo Acceio Cnaei filio Arnensi Rufo Lutatio Tito Petillio Publi filio Quirina IIviris
decreta
aediculam et statuas has hostiam dedicationi victimae natali Augusti VIII kalendas Octobres duae quae perpetuo
immolari adsuetae sunt ad aram quae Numini Augusto dedicata est VIIII et VIII kalendas Octobres
inmolerentur item natali Tiberi Caesaris perpetuae acturi decuriones
et populus cenarent quam inpensam Quinto Caecellio Labeone
in perpetuo pollicenti ut gratiae agerentur munificentiae eius eoque
natali ut quotannis vitulus inmolaretur
ut ut natalibus Augusti Tiberi Caesarum prius quam ad vescendum
decuriones irent thure et vino Genii eorum ad epulandum ara
Numinis Augusti invitarentur
ara Numini Augusto pecunia nostra faciendam curavimus ludos
ex idibus Augustis diebus sex pecunia nostra faciendos curavimus
natali Augustae mulsum et crustlum mulieribus vicanis ad
Bonam Deam pecunia nostra dedimus
item dedicatione statuarum Caesarum et Augustae mulsum et crustla
pecunia nosstra decurionibus et populo dedimus perpetuoque eius die
dedicationis daturonos testati sumus quem diem quo frequentior quod
annis sit servabimus VI idus Martias qua die
Tiberius Caesar pontifex maximus felicissime est creatus

div.p: This inscription purports to recount a decision of the decurions of Forum Clodii of 18 CE, but is undeniably also capturing earlier relevant decisions of the same decurions from earlier (Gradel 2002, 242–244; Scheid 2005, 239 n. 83; Koortbojian 2013: 172). Nonetheless, the decree tells us that that an aedicula ('shrine'), statues, and hostia ('animal sacrifice') had been voted, sacrifices had been prescribed for the birthdays of Augustus, Tiberius and Livia Augustus, that they have had an ara ('altar') to the Numen Augustum built, that games have been held, and that wine and cakes would be distributed to the people. It is very likely that the statues of the Caesars mentioned in line 17, are attested through surviving statue bases, all discovered in the same location: see EmpWor000867, EmpWor000868, EmpWor000869 and EmpWor000870. The inscription attests to robust engagement with emperor worship in Forum Clodii, in ways that fit local circumstances and reflect the priorities of members of the local elite: the celebration of Livia's birthday was to be the day when Forum Clodii would publicly celebrate the Bona Dea, the local euergete Q. Cascellius Labeo used Tiberius' birthday to cement his legacy to the peoples of Forum Clodii by promising to cover the expense of banquets for the princeps' birthday in perpetuity, and the decuriones used the opportunity to remind everyone that they were heavily involved in all grand acts of civic munificence. Whereas Gradel (2002, 249–250) tries to situate this inscription in line with imperial innovation – Augustus should be called a divus in an inscription of 18 CE, and divi should have been given steers as the 'proper' sacrifice. By contrast, I believe the inscription is an important marker of the tensions between innovation and tradition in early emperor worship. Why should Forum Clodii have changed their forms of worship to comply with imperial innovation? The decree itself stresses that the decurions of Forum Clodii were trying to strike a precarious balance between innovation and continuity: that they were adapting older features to accommodate new scenarios (such as the emergence of the new princeps Tiberius), but without contradicting their earlier committments to undertaking forms of emperor worship in perpeuity. The decree stresses that the decurions of Forum Clodii had ensured that the nature of their worship had not changed, that they were not abandoning their pre-existing religious vocabulary, but were merely updating their practices in ways that suited them. For the importance of the Cascelli in Forum Clodii, see CIL 11.7556. For attempts to reconstruct the development of worship at Forum Clodii, see Marengo (2005: 54–60); Gasperini (2008b); Koortbojian (2013: 172–178). Gradel (2002, 249) argues that this altar was directly inspired by the altar to the numen Augusti at Narbo (in Narbonese Gaul): CIL 12.4333. He argues that Q. Cascellius Labeo, who we know from his epitaph (CIL 6.3510) was a praefectus fabrum and of the tribe Voltinia, and probably himself came from Gallia Narbonensis, judging by the other extant Cascellii in that region and his tribal affiliation. While Gradel is correct that there were Cascellii in the province of Gallia Narbonensis (see e.g. CIL 12.2689, 12.4194, 12.4334, 12.3210; ILGN 436) members of the family are equally spread across Italy, even by a very early date (see esp. CIL 11.1966, 11.3246; AE 1999.628). After not having been seen for more than 120 years, after Bormann and Henzen had recorded the stone, the decree was imagined lost until Gasperini (2008a) managed to trace its movements and finally to autopsy the stone itself.
